title: How to Make Clay Topped Stick Pins

steps.headline: Knead the clay to make it soft.
Roll the clay into little ball shapes.
steps.description:
Use the balls to make shapes as follows:
Keep in a ball shape
Push into cone shapes
Twist two balls together to make a braided sausage shape
Any other shapes that grab your fancy.

steps.headline: Decorate.
steps.description: This step is optional but if you want to stick small seed beads or similar onto the clay, do so before it dries.

steps.headline: Press the molded shape onto the T-end or round end of the stick pin.
steps.description: Two balls, cones, etc. can be pressed end to end of the stick pin or a round ball can cover the whole end. It all depends on what you're aiming to cover on the stick pin and the best fit for the clay decoration.

steps.headline: Place the pins onto a glass baking dish.
steps.description: Follow the manufacturer's instructions for baking them.

steps.headline: Allow to cool completely before use.
steps.description: When not in use, store in a suitable container to prevent breakage.

text:
Knead the clay to make it soft. Use warm, clean hands. Roll the clay into little ball shapes. Use the balls to make shapes as follows:
Keep in a ball shape
Push into cone shapes
Twist two balls together to make a braided sausage shape
Any other shapes that grab your fancy. Decorate. This step is optional but if you want to stick small seed beads or similar onto the clay, do so before it dries. Press the molded shape onto the T-end or round end of the stick pin. Two balls, cones, etc. can be pressed end to end of the stick pin or a round ball can cover the whole end. It all depends on what you're aiming to cover on the stick pin and the best fit for the clay decoration. Place the pins onto a glass baking dish. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for baking them. Allow to cool completely before use. When not in use, store in a suitable container to prevent breakage.
